str2: A primary particle; but, and, etc.
Paul, Paulus. Of Latin origin; Paulus, the name of a Roman and of an apostle.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Genitive Masculine Singular
str2: A strengthened form of melo; to intend, i.e. Be about to be, do, or suffer something.
To open. From ana and oigo; to open up.
Of Latin origin; Gallion, a Roman officer.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: Answer, bid, bring word, command. A primary verb; to speak or say.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Jewish. From Iouda; Judaean, i.e. Belonging to Jehudah.
If. A primary particle of conditionality; if, whether, that, etc.

parse: Verb - Imperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.

parse: Interrogative / Indefinite Pronoun - Nominative Neuter Singular
str2: Any one, some one, a certain one or thing. An enclitic indefinite pronoun; some or any person or object.
A legal wrong, crime (with which one is charged), misdeed, crime against God, a sin. From adikeo; a wrong done.
Or, than. A primary particle of distinction between two connected terms; disjunctive, or; comparative, than.
Evil, bad, wicked, malicious, slothful.
A careless action, an act of villainy. From a comparative of rhaidios and ergon; easy-going behavior, i.e. a crime.
A primary interjection; as a sign of the vocative case, O; as a note of exclamation, oh.
Jewish. From Iouda; Judaean, i.e. Belonging to Jehudah.
From lego; something said; by implication, a topic, also reasoning or motive; by extension, a computation; specially, the Divine Expression.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Middle - 1st Person Singular
str2: To endure, bear with, have patience with, suffer, admit, persist.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Genitive 2nd Person Plural
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
